The things all us ladies have to put up with. Take care of yourself.  Karen

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2008 08:39PM KKing wrote: Hello October ladies...hope you don't mind me dropping by.  I am a Junie and just finished my 6th treatment 12 days ago...so my chemo is finished.  I just wanted to let you all know that it is truly doable.   You will have some bad days but I found that I went every three weeks for treatment and that for about 5 days after treatment I did go through some rough patches but then you feel normal again until the next treatment.  As for the Neulasta shot... I did get it in my stomach...didn't hurt and it truly helps with the white blood count.   I went through 3 FEC and 3 Taxotere.   FEC caused more nausea and things but get the right meds for that.    The steroids with Taxotere made you feel pretty good so it wasn't as hard to take.   I did take some painkillers during the Taxotere onlybecause it can cause some bone pain  but nothing too serious. I want to wish you all well with your treatments and if you have anything you are concerned about just ask.  You can PM me or come over ot the June group and ask there. Best wishes,  Karen
Posts.Title: Anyone starting chemo in October 08? SuzyWillKickThis unique

Posts.Content: Sep 14, 2010 10:02PM KKing wrote:   I was diagnosed stage 2 , 1 lymph node.  I was put through all scans before the chemo.  I dont know if that is just standard here in Canada.  The onc explained that they check the lungs with a chest xray.  An abdomen ultrasound to check the liver and a full bone scan for the bones.  Everything was negative...thank God.  Just wanted to share this with you.

Hope this helps. Karen

Posts.Title: How many years have you been a Survivor? IllinoisNancy Lou789

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2008 01:36PM KKing wrote: Deirdre I have had the three fec treatments and just finished by second taxotere... only one to go. For me, the fec made me sick for a couple of days and then I was pretty good for the rest of the time.   As the treatments progressed,   I was just more fatigued than anything.   As for the taxotere,  no sickness, but I am finding about 3 days after, it does cause some bone pain.  I am taking tylenol 3 and that seems to be working better this time.   I have to say that it does play havoc on your body but with the 3 week break,  your body is able to take the next one.   Big things that worked for me were drinking lots of fluid... flushes it out of your system.    Biotene mouthwash when my mouth starts to feel weird.   Try to eat when you can so that your body is being fed... even if you don't feel like eating.   If you found the first treatment not too bad,  I am sure you will do well.   Remember, look after yourself first and rest when you need to. Hope this helps...  take care Karen
Posts.Title: FEC? DFOnt IrishTwin

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2008 12:37PM KKing wrote: I am scheduled for radiation therapy in October. I asked my doctor what the benefit would be if I undergo the radiation and he said without it I could have up to 34% chance of recurrence but with it..it drops to 10%.   So I signed on the dotted line.
Posts.Title: RADIATION INCREASES SURVIVABILITY OF HIGH RISK PATIENTS. worriedhubby MarieKelly

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2009 07:38PM KKing wrote: wow. sorry you are feeling so sick.  I did do three sessions of FEC and three of Taxotere.  I have to admit the taxotere was harder to take than the FEC.  A really important thing when undergoing chemo is to stay hydrated...even if you think you can't drink something.  Drink whatever you can, water, juice, pop, tea...It will get the chemo out of your system quicker.  Maybe it is the dose dense that is killing you.  Can they lesson the doses so you are not as sick.   I know you want to give it up but don't... it does seem like it will never end but it does and you will feel better again.    Just think that this stuff is killing any leftover cancer in the body and you will come out the other side.  Hang in there. Karen
Posts.Title: I'm ready to just say no NAZSusan Seabee

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2009 07:20PM KKing wrote: Maria I finished 21 treatments in November. I must say that fatigue was not an issue for me.  Mind you, I wasn't working then.   I had skin problems by the end and recommend airing out your skin throughout the procedure.  If I had done that, I would not have had any problems.   Good luck. Karen
